annotation.spannedText: Rabies vaccine must never be given into the gluteal muscle due to the risk of a decreased immune response

annotation.spannedText: HDCV or PCECV administered at the same time as RabIg (using a separate needle, syringe and injection site) and local treatment are highly effective in preventing rabies in exposed individuals

classMention.mentionClass: HDCV or PCECV administered at the same time as RabIg (using a separate needle, syringe and injection site) and local treatment are highly effective in preventing rabies in exposed individuals

annotation.spannedText: The immunogenicity of PCECV and HDCV for pre-exposure vaccination has been demonstrated in clinical trials

classMention.mentionClass: The immunogenicity of PCECV and HDCV for pre-exposure vaccination has been demonstrated in clinical trials

annotation.spannedText: Pre-exposure rabies immunization with either HDCV or PCECV should be offered to people at high risk of close contact with rabid animals or the rabies virus

classMention.mentionClass: Pre-exposure rabies immunization with either HDCV or PCECV should be offered to people at high risk of close contact with rabid animals or the rabies virus

annotation.spannedText: Rabies prophylaxis must be considered in every incident in which human exposure to potentially rabid animals has occurred, unless rabies is known to be absent from the local animal population

classMention.mentionClass: Rabies prophylaxis must be considered in every incident in which human exposure to potentially rabid animals has occurred, unless rabies is known to be absent from the local animal population

annotation.spannedText: In evaluating each case, local public health officials should be consulted

annotation.spannedText: When considering the need for post-exposure management, the following should be reviewed

classMention.mentionClass: When considering the need for post-exposure management, the following should be reviewed

annotation.spannedText: Petting a rabid animal or handling its blood, urine or feces is not considered to be an exposure; however, such contact should be avoided

classMention.mentionClass: Petting a rabid animal or handling its blood, urine or feces is not considered to be an exposure; however, such contact should be avoided

annotation.spannedText: post-exposure prophylaxis should be considered for individuals exposed to saliva or neural tissue from a person with rabies

classMention.mentionClass: post-exposure prophylaxis should be considered for individuals exposed to saliva or neural tissue from a person with rabies

annotation.spannedText: Bites inflicted on a person attempting to feed or handle an apparently healthy animal should generally be regarded as provoked

classMention.mentionClass: Bites inflicted on a person attempting to feed or handle an apparently healthy animal should generally be regarded as provoked

annotation.spannedText: Untrained individuals should never handle wild or stray animals or any domestic animal that is behaving unusually and children should be taught this precaution

classMention.mentionClass: Untrained individuals should never handle wild or stray animals or any domestic animal that is behaving unusually and children should be taught this precaution

annotation.spannedText: A veterinarian should be consulted to determine if the animal is up-to-date with its vaccinations

classMention.mentionClass: A veterinarian should be consulted to determine if the animal is up-to-date with its vaccinations

annotation.spannedText: Any domestic dog, cat or ferret (regardless of vaccination history) that has bitten a human should be reported to public health officials for appropriate follow-up

classMention.mentionClass: Any domestic dog, cat or ferret (regardless of vaccination history) that has bitten a human should be reported to public health officials for appropriate follow-up

annotation.spannedText: Generally, behaviour in wild animals cannot be accurately evaluated and should not be considered part of the risk assessment

classMention.mentionClass: Generally, behaviour in wild animals cannot be accurately evaluated and should not be considered part of the risk assessment

annotation.spannedText: This factor should be considered when determining the appropriate post-exposure management

classMention.mentionClass: This factor should be considered when determining the appropriate post-exposure management

annotation.spannedText: Post-exposure prophylaxis should not be delayed beyond 48 hours while waiting for test results in wild animals

classMention.mentionClass: Post-exposure prophylaxis should not be delayed beyond 48 hours while waiting for test results in wild animals

annotation.spannedText: If the dog, cat or ferret has or develops signs of rabies, post-exposure prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible

classMention.mentionClass: If the dog, cat or ferret has or develops signs of rabies, post-exposure prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible

annotation.spannedText: Any animal that has bitten a human or is suspected of being rabid should be reported to local public health officials

classMention.mentionClass: Any animal that has bitten a human or is suspected of being rabid should be reported to local public health officials

annotation.spannedText: Exposures to dogs, cats and ferrets that could potentially result in rabies transmission (as described in Type of exposure) should be reported to local public health officials

classMention.mentionClass: Exposures to dogs, cats and ferrets that could potentially result in rabies transmission (as described in Type of exposure) should be reported to local public health officials

annotation.spannedText: Dogs, cats and ferrets that are apparently healthy should be confined and observed for 10 days after a bite, regardless of the animal's rabies vaccination status

classMention.mentionClass: Dogs, cats and ferrets that are apparently healthy should be confined and observed for 10 days after a bite, regardless of the animal's rabies vaccination status

annotation.spannedText: If illness suggestive of rabies exists at the time of the bite or develops during the observation period, the animal should be humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for laboratory examination and rabies testing

classMention.mentionClass: If illness suggestive of rabies exists at the time of the bite or develops during the observation period, the animal should be humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for laboratory examination and rabies testing

annotation.spannedText: The CFIA veterinarian should be contacted to assist with determining the need for testing, organizing the testing and following-up potential exposures to other domestic animals

classMention.mentionClass: The CFIA veterinarian should be contacted to assist with determining the need for testing, organizing the testing and following-up potential exposures to other domestic animals

annotation.spannedText: The person responsible for observation of the animal should be advised to notify public health officials if the animal becomes ill or escapes during the observation period

classMention.mentionClass: The person responsible for observation of the animal should be advised to notify public health officials if the animal becomes ill or escapes during the observation period

annotation.spannedText: The animal should be observed by a public health official or veterinarian at the end of the 10-day observation period to ensure that it is alive and healthy

classMention.mentionClass: The animal should be observed by a public health official or veterinarian at the end of the 10-day observation period to ensure that it is alive and healthy

annotation.spannedText: Unvaccinated animals that remain healthy should be vaccinated at the end of the observation period

classMention.mentionClass: Unvaccinated animals that remain healthy should be vaccinated at the end of the observation period

annotation.spannedText: Stray or unwanted dogs, cats or ferrets involved in an exposure that could potentially transmit rabies should be confined and observed as outlined above

classMention.mentionClass: Stray or unwanted dogs, cats or ferrets involved in an exposure that could potentially transmit rabies should be confined and observed as outlined above

annotation.spannedText: If this is not possible, the animal should be humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for laboratory examination and rabies testing in consultation with the local CFIA veterinarian

classMention.mentionClass: If this is not possible, the animal should be humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for laboratory examination and rabies testing in consultation with the local CFIA veterinarian

annotation.spannedText: If the dog, cat or ferret has escaped, attempts should be made to find the animal and owner

classMention.mentionClass: If the dog, cat or ferret has escaped, attempts should be made to find the animal and owner

annotation.spannedText: If the dog, cat or ferret cannot be located, a decision should be made in consultation with public health officials regarding the need for post-exposure prophylaxis

classMention.mentionClass: If the dog, cat or ferret cannot be located, a decision should be made in consultation with public health officials regarding the need for post-exposure prophylaxis

annotation.spannedText: The period of rabies virus shedding in a wild terrestrial carnivore (such as a skunk, fox or raccoon) or in an exotic pet (other than a ferret) is unknown. Therefore, when these animals are involved in an exposure that could potentially transmit rabies, a trained wildlife or animal control worker should be contacted to capture the animal

annotation.spannedText: The worker should use extreme caution to ensure that there is no further exposure to the animal

classMention.mentionClass: The worker should use extreme caution to ensure that there is no further exposure to the animal

annotation.spannedText: The animal should be immediately humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for laboratory examination and rabies testing in consultation with the local CFIA veterinarian

annotation.spannedText: the bat should not be captured for testing and should be safely released

annotation.spannedText: To remove a bat from a building, the area with the bat should be closed off from the rest of the building and people and pets kept out of the area

classMention.mentionClass: To remove a bat from a building, the area with the bat should be closed off from the rest of the building and people and pets kept out of the area

annotation.spannedText: The doors or windows in the area with the bat should be opened to the exterior to let the bat escape

classMention.mentionClass: The doors or windows in the area with the bat should be opened to the exterior to let the bat escape

annotation.spannedText: If there has been direct contact with a bat (as defined in Bat exposure), a trained wildlife or animal control worker should be contacted to attempt to capture the bat

classMention.mentionClass: If there has been direct contact with a bat (as defined in Bat exposure), a trained wildlife or animal control worker should be contacted to attempt to capture the bat

annotation.spannedText: The worker should use extreme caution to ensure that there is no further exposure to the bat

classMention.mentionClass: The worker should use extreme caution to ensure that there is no further exposure to the bat

annotation.spannedText: She or he should wear thick leather gloves, should avoid touching the bat, and should place the intact bat in a closed secure container

classMention.mentionClass: She or he should wear thick leather gloves, should avoid touching the bat, and should place the intact bat in a closed secure container

annotation.spannedText: Once the bat has been captured, local public health officials should be contacted

classMention.mentionClass: Once the bat has been captured, local public health officials should be contacted

annotation.spannedText: Bats should be submitted intact for rabies testing, i.e. they should not be decapitated

classMention.mentionClass: Bats should be submitted intact for rabies testing, i.e. they should not be decapitated

annotation.spannedText: Care should be taken to clean the wound to its full depth

classMention.mentionClass: Care should be taken to clean the wound to its full depth

annotation.spannedText: Suturing the wound should be avoided if possible, and tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotics should be given as appropriate

classMention.mentionClass: Suturing the wound should be avoided if possible, and tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotics should be given as appropriate

annotation.spannedText: If exposure to rabies is considered highly likely, post-exposure prophylaxis should be started as soon as possible after the exposure

classMention.mentionClass: If exposure to rabies is considered highly likely, post-exposure prophylaxis should be started as soon as possible after the exposure

annotation.spannedText: If indicated, based on the risk assessment, post-exposure prophylaxis should be offered to exposed individuals regardless of the time interval after exposure

classMention.mentionClass: If indicated, based on the risk assessment, post-exposure prophylaxis should be offered to exposed individuals regardless of the time interval after exposure

annotation.spannedText: The animal should be humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for immediate laboratory examination and rabies testing. In consultation with public health officials, post-exposure prophylaxis may be discontinued if the animal tests negative for rabies

classMention.mentionClass: The animal should be humanely euthanized in a way that does as little damage to the brain as possible, and the head submitted for immediate laboratory examination and rabies testing. In consultation with public health officials, post-exposure prophylaxis may be discontinued if the animal tests negative for rabies

annotation.spannedText: If the dog, cat or ferret has escaped and cannot be located, a decision should be made in consultation with public health officials regarding the need for post-exposure prophylaxis

classMention.mentionClass: If the dog, cat or ferret has escaped and cannot be located, a decision should be made in consultation with public health officials regarding the need for post-exposure prophylaxis

annotation.spannedText: The decision should consider several factors, including the rate of occurrence of rabies in the area, if it was a domestic or stray animal, the type of exposure, the circumstances of the exposure, including whether it was a provoked or unprovoked exposure, and the severity and location of the wound

classMention.mentionClass: The decision should consider several factors, including the rate of occurrence of rabies in the area, if it was a domestic or stray animal, the type of exposure, the circumstances of the exposure, including whether it was a provoked or unprovoked exposure, and the severity and location of the wound

annotation.spannedText: The decision to start post-exposure prophylaxis while awaiting the laboratory test results should consider several factors, including when the test results will be available, the species of animal, the rate of occurrence of rabies in that species and in other species in the area, the type of exposure, the circumstances of the exposure including whether it was a provoked or unprovoked exposure, and the severity and locations of the wounds

classMention.mentionClass: The decision to start post-exposure prophylaxis while awaiting the laboratory test results should consider several factors, including when the test results will be available, the species of animal, the rate of occurrence of rabies in that species and in other species in the area, the type of exposure, the circumstances of the exposure including whether it was a provoked or unprovoked exposure, and the severity and locations of the wounds

annotation.spannedText: Initiation of post-exposure prophylaxis should not be delayed beyond 48 hours while waiting for laboratory tests, if the exposure is from a terrestrial animal in an enzootic area

classMention.mentionClass: Initiation of post-exposure prophylaxis should not be delayed beyond 48 hours while waiting for laboratory tests, if the exposure is from a terrestrial animal in an enzootic area

annotation.spannedText: If post-exposure prophylaxis is started before the test results are available, in consultation with public health officials, the rabies vaccine may be discontinued if the animal tests negative for rabies

classMention.mentionClass: If post-exposure prophylaxis is started before the test results are available, in consultation with public health officials, the rabies vaccine may be discontinued if the animal tests negative for rabies

annotation.spannedText: When there is a known bat bite, scratch or saliva exposure into a wound or mucous membrane, rabies post-exposure prophylaxis should be initiated immediately because of the higher prevalence of rabies in bats

classMention.mentionClass: When there is a known bat bite, scratch or saliva exposure into a wound or mucous membrane, rabies post-exposure prophylaxis should be initiated immediately because of the higher prevalence of rabies in bats

annotation.spannedText: It is particularly important to do so when the exposure involves the face, neck or hands, or when the behaviour of the bat is clearly abnormal, such as a bat that attacks a person or hangs on tenaciously

classMention.mentionClass: It is particularly important to do so when the exposure involves the face, neck or hands, or when the behaviour of the bat is clearly abnormal, such as a bat that attacks a person or hangs on tenaciously

annotation.spannedText: If a bat tests positive for rabies, the need for post-exposure prophylaxis should depend on whether direct contact with the bat occurred and not the rabies status of the bat

classMention.mentionClass: If a bat tests positive for rabies, the need for post-exposure prophylaxis should depend on whether direct contact with the bat occurred and not the rabies status of the bat

annotation.spannedText: If a person is touched by a bat (such as a bat in flight) and the bat is available for rabies testing, the health care provider may decide to delay post-exposure prophylaxis

classMention.mentionClass: If a person is touched by a bat (such as a bat in flight) and the bat is available for rabies testing, the health care provider may decide to delay post-exposure prophylaxis

annotation.spannedText: If a person is touched by a bat, but the bat is not available for testing it should be considered a direct contact and post-exposure prophylaxis should be given

classMention.mentionClass: If a person is touched by a bat, but the bat is not available for testing it should be considered a direct contact and post-exposure prophylaxis should be given

annotation.spannedText: Pregnancy and breastfeeding are not contraindications to post-exposure rabies prophylaxis, but it is prudent to delay pre-exposure immunization of pregnant women unless there is a substantial risk of exposure

classMention.mentionClass: Pregnancy and breastfeeding are not contraindications to post-exposure rabies prophylaxis, but it is prudent to delay pre-exposure immunization of pregnant women unless there is a substantial risk of exposure

annotation.spannedText: Because of suboptimal response, in general, immunocompromised persons should be counselled to avoid situations of rabies exposure

classMention.mentionClass: Because of suboptimal response, in general, immunocompromised persons should be counselled to avoid situations of rabies exposure

annotation.spannedText: If possible, pre-exposure immunization should be delayed in immunocompromised individuals until the immunocompromised state has resolved

classMention.mentionClass: If possible, pre-exposure immunization should be delayed in immunocompromised individuals until the immunocompromised state has resolved

annotation.spannedText: In situations in which immunosuppression is planned (such as before organ transplant) and pre-exposure rabies vaccine is necessary, the vaccine series should be given only by the intramuscular route and should be completed at least 14 days prior to starting immunosuppression if possible

classMention.mentionClass: In situations in which immunosuppression is planned (such as before organ transplant) and pre-exposure rabies vaccine is necessary, the vaccine series should be given only by the intramuscular route and should be completed at least 14 days prior to starting immunosuppression if possible

annotation.spannedText: If pre-exposure vaccination of an immunocompromised person is considered necessary because animal exposure cannot be avoided and the immunocompromising condition cannot be corrected, the vaccination should be given only by the intramuscular route and serology should be checked 7 to 14 days post-vaccination to ensure that an acceptable antibody response has developed

classMention.mentionClass: If pre-exposure vaccination of an immunocompromised person is considered necessary because animal exposure cannot be avoided and the immunocompromising condition cannot be corrected, the vaccination should be given only by the intramuscular route and serology should be checked 7 to 14 days post-vaccination to ensure that an acceptable antibody response has developed

annotation.spannedText: When post-exposure prophylaxis is administered to an immunocompromised person, a full five-dose series (days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28 days) should be used along with one dose of RabIg on day 0; serology should be checked 7 to 14 days after completion of the series to ensure that an acceptable antibody response has developed

classMention.mentionClass: When post-exposure prophylaxis is administered to an immunocompromised person, a full five-dose series (days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28 days) should be used along with one dose of RabIg on day 0; serology should be checked 7 to 14 days after completion of the series to ensure that an acceptable antibody response has developed

annotation.spannedText: If no acceptable antibody response is detected, the patient should be managed in consultation with their physician and appropriate public health officials to receive a second rabies vaccine series

classMention.mentionClass: If no acceptable antibody response is detected, the patient should be managed in consultation with their physician and appropriate public health officials to receive a second rabies vaccine series

annotation.spannedText: RabIg should not be repeated at the initiation of this second course

classMention.mentionClass: RabIg should not be repeated at the initiation of this second course

annotation.spannedText: Immunosuppressive agents should not be administered during post-exposure prophylaxis unless essential for the treatment of other conditions

classMention.mentionClass: Immunosuppressive agents should not be administered during post-exposure prophylaxis unless essential for the treatment of other conditions

annotation.spannedText: Travellers to rabies endemic areas where there is poor access to adequate and safe post-exposure management, as well as frequent and long-term travellers to high risk areas, should seriously consider receiving pre-travel rabies immunization

classMention.mentionClass: Travellers to rabies endemic areas where there is poor access to adequate and safe post-exposure management, as well as frequent and long-term travellers to high risk areas, should seriously consider receiving pre-travel rabies immunization

annotation.spannedText: Children, especially those who are too young to understand the need both to avoid animals and to report a traumatic contact, are considered at greater risk of rabid animal exposure and should receive pre-exposure immunization when travelling to endemic areas

classMention.mentionClass: Children, especially those who are too young to understand the need both to avoid animals and to report a traumatic contact, are considered at greater risk of rabid animal exposure and should receive pre-exposure immunization when travelling to endemic areas

annotation.spannedText: Public health officials should be consulted regarding travellers who have had an exposure to a potentially rabid animal in a developing country, even if the traveller received a complete course of post-exposure prophylaxis in that country

classMention.mentionClass: Public health officials should be consulted regarding travellers who have had an exposure to a potentially rabid animal in a developing country, even if the traveller received a complete course of post-exposure prophylaxis in that country

annotation.spannedText: Pre-exposure rabies immunization should be offered to workers at high risk of occupational exposure to potentially rabid animals or to the rabies virus

classMention.mentionClass: Pre-exposure rabies immunization should be offered to workers at high risk of occupational exposure to potentially rabid animals or to the rabies virus

annotation.spannedText: Three doses of HDCV or PCECV are required and should be given on days 0, 7 and any time between days 21 to 28

classMention.mentionClass: Three doses of HDCV or PCECV are required and should be given on days 0, 7 and any time between days 21 to 28

annotation.spannedText: Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal muscle due to variable immune response

classMention.mentionClass: Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal muscle due to variable immune response

annotation.spannedText: The ID route should not be used in persons who are immunocompromised due to illness or medication, or are taking chloroquine, as the immune response to the vaccine may not be protective under these circumstances

classMention.mentionClass: The ID route should not be used in persons who are immunocompromised due to illness or medication, or are taking chloroquine, as the immune response to the vaccine may not be protective under these circumstances

annotation.spannedText: In these individuals, vaccine should be administered by the IM route only

classMention.mentionClass: In these individuals, vaccine should be administered by the IM route only

annotation.spannedText: If the intradermal route is used, rabies vaccine should be administered only by fully trained staff in settings in which there is a well-established cold chain

classMention.mentionClass: If the intradermal route is used, rabies vaccine should be administered only by fully trained staff in settings in which there is a well-established cold chain

annotation.spannedText: Improper technique may result in a suboptimal dose of vaccine being administered or inadvertent subcutaneous injection of the vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: Improper technique may result in a suboptimal dose of vaccine being administered or inadvertent subcutaneous injection of the vaccine

annotation.spannedText: The use of the proper syringe and needle is essential to ensure that the correct route and dose are used

classMention.mentionClass: The use of the proper syringe and needle is essential to ensure that the correct route and dose are used

annotation.spannedText: Vaccine wastage should be minimized by immunizing enough individuals at the same time to use all of the contents of a vial of vaccine, whenever possible

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccine wastage should be minimized by immunizing enough individuals at the same time to use all of the contents of a vial of vaccine, whenever possible

annotation.spannedText: When rabies vaccine is administered ID, post-immunization antibody titres should be determined at least 2 weeks after completion of the vaccine series to ensure that an acceptable level of protection has been achieved

classMention.mentionClass: When rabies vaccine is administered ID, post-immunization antibody titres should be determined at least 2 weeks after completion of the vaccine series to ensure that an acceptable level of protection has been achieved

annotation.spannedText: If using the ID route for a booster dose, serology should be checked at least 2 weeks after the booster dose

classMention.mentionClass: If using the ID route for a booster dose, serology should be checked at least 2 weeks after the booster dose

annotation.spannedText: Post-exposure prophylaxis of previously unimmunized individuals should consist of both RabIg and rabies vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: Post-exposure prophylaxis of previously unimmunized individuals should consist of both RabIg and rabies vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Because of possible interference of RabIg with the immune response to the rabies vaccine, the dose of RabIg should not be exceeded

classMention.mentionClass: Because of possible interference of RabIg with the immune response to the rabies vaccine, the dose of RabIg should not be exceeded

annotation.spannedText: If possible, the full dose of RabIg should be thoroughly infiltrated into the wound and surrounding area

classMention.mentionClass: If possible, the full dose of RabIg should be thoroughly infiltrated into the wound and surrounding area

annotation.spannedText: Any remaining volume of RabIg should be injected intramuscularly, using a separate needle, at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration

classMention.mentionClass: Any remaining volume of RabIg should be injected intramuscularly, using a separate needle, at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration

annotation.spannedText: When more than one wound exists, each wound should be locally infiltrated with a portion of the RabIg using a separate needle

classMention.mentionClass: When more than one wound exists, each wound should be locally infiltrated with a portion of the RabIg using a separate needle

annotation.spannedText: If the site of the wound is unknown, the entire dose should be administered intramuscularly at a separate site from the administration of rabies vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: If the site of the wound is unknown, the entire dose should be administered intramuscularly at a separate site from the administration of rabies vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Rabies vaccine and RabIg should never be mixed in the same syringe

classMention.mentionClass: Rabies vaccine and RabIg should never be mixed in the same syringe

annotation.spannedText: If RabIg is not administered as recommended at the initiation of the rabies vaccine series, it should be administered up to and including day 7 after vaccine is initiated but should not be administered after that time

classMention.mentionClass: If RabIg is not administered as recommended at the initiation of the rabies vaccine series, it should be administered up to and including day 7 after vaccine is initiated but should not be administered after that time

annotation.spannedText: For post-exposure prophylaxis of immunocompetent persons previously unimmunized with rabies vaccine, four 1.0mL doses of HDCV or PCECV should be administered IM

classMention.mentionClass: For post-exposure prophylaxis of immunocompetent persons previously unimmunized with rabies vaccine, four 1.0mL doses of HDCV or PCECV should be administered IM

annotation.spannedText: The first dose (day0) of the four-dose course of rabies vaccine should be administered as soon as possible after exposure based on the considerations discussed in the Management of the person after exposure to a potentially rabid animal section

classMention.mentionClass: The first dose (day0) of the four-dose course of rabies vaccine should be administered as soon as possible after exposure based on the considerations discussed in the Management of the person after exposure to a potentially rabid animal section

annotation.spannedText: Additional doses should be administered on days3, 7 and14 after the first vaccination

classMention.mentionClass: Additional doses should be administered on days3, 7 and14 after the first vaccination

annotation.spannedText: Vaccine should be administered IM into the deltoid muscle in older children and adults or into the vastus lateralis muscle (anterolateral thigh) in infants, but never in the gluteal region as this may result in decreased response to the vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccine should be administered IM into the deltoid muscle in older children and adults or into the vastus lateralis muscle (anterolateral thigh) in infants, but never in the gluteal region as this may result in decreased response to the vaccine

annotation.spannedText: The rabies vaccine and RabIg should be given at different anatomical sites on day 0, using a separate needle and syringe

classMention.mentionClass: The rabies vaccine and RabIg should be given at different anatomical sites on day 0, using a separate needle and syringe

annotation.spannedText: The vaccination schedule for post-exposure prophylaxis should be adhered to as closely as possible and it is essential that all recommended doses of vaccine be administered

classMention.mentionClass: The vaccination schedule for post-exposure prophylaxis should be adhered to as closely as possible and it is essential that all recommended doses of vaccine be administered

annotation.spannedText: Although there is little or no evidence, in keeping with routine immunization practice, it is recommended that, if a dose of vaccine is given at less than the recommended interval, that dose should be ignored and the dose given at the appropriate interval from the previous dose

classMention.mentionClass: Although there is little or no evidence, in keeping with routine immunization practice, it is recommended that, if a dose of vaccine is given at less than the recommended interval, that dose should be ignored and the dose given at the appropriate interval from the previous dose

annotation.spannedText: If a dose of vaccine is delayed, it should be given as soon as possible and the schedule resumed, respecting the appropriate intervals from the latest dose

classMention.mentionClass: If a dose of vaccine is delayed, it should be given as soon as possible and the schedule resumed, respecting the appropriate intervals from the latest dose

annotation.spannedText: If the vaccination schedule has been altered and there is doubt about a sufficient immune response, post-vaccination serology should be obtained 7 to 14 days after completing the vaccination series

classMention.mentionClass: If the vaccination schedule has been altered and there is doubt about a sufficient immune response, post-vaccination serology should be obtained 7 to 14 days after completing the vaccination series

annotation.spannedText: RabIg is not indicated and should not be given to someone who has been previously appropriately immunized as indicated below

classMention.mentionClass: RabIg is not indicated and should not be given to someone who has been previously appropriately immunized as indicated below

annotation.spannedText: People with ongoing high risk of exposure and inadequate titres should be given a booster dose of either rabies vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: People with ongoing high risk of exposure and inadequate titres should be given a booster dose of either rabies vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Both HDCV and PCECV have been shown to be effective in boosting immunity in previously immunized individuals, if given either as a pre-exposure booster or for post-exposure management

classMention.mentionClass: Both HDCV and PCECV have been shown to be effective in boosting immunity in previously immunized individuals, if given either as a pre-exposure booster or for post-exposure management

annotation.spannedText: In this circumstance, antibody concentration should be checked at least 2 weeks after completion of the vaccine series

classMention.mentionClass: In this circumstance, antibody concentration should be checked at least 2 weeks after completion of the vaccine series

annotation.spannedText: If using the ID route for a booster dose, serology should be checked at least 2 weeks after the booster dose

classMention.mentionClass: If using the ID route for a booster dose, serology should be checked at least 2 weeks after the booster dose

annotation.spannedText: antibody concentration should be checked 7 to 14 days after completing the series

classMention.mentionClass: antibody concentration should be checked 7 to 14 days after completing the series

annotation.spannedText: In this circumstance, antibody concentration should be checked at least 7 to 14 days after completing the series

classMention.mentionClass: In this circumstance, antibody concentration should be checked at least 7 to 14 days after completing the series

annotation.spannedText: Frequent risk (rabies diagnostic laboratory workers; spelunkers; those who frequently handle bats; veterinarians, veterinary staff, animal control and wildlife workers in areas where rabies is enzootic) - serology should be checked every 2 years

classMention.mentionClass: Frequent risk (rabies diagnostic laboratory workers; spelunkers; those who frequently handle bats; veterinarians, veterinary staff, animal control and wildlife workers in areas where rabies is enzootic) - serology should be checked every 2 years

annotation.spannedText: If it is possible to avoid exposure to rabies, pre-exposure immunization should be deferred in immunocompromised people until they are no longer immunocompromised

classMention.mentionClass: If it is possible to avoid exposure to rabies, pre-exposure immunization should be deferred in immunocompromised people until they are no longer immunocompromised

annotation.spannedText: If pre-exposure immunization must be given to immunocompromised individuals, antibody response should be determined after completion of the series

classMention.mentionClass: If pre-exposure immunization must be given to immunocompromised individuals, antibody response should be determined after completion of the series

annotation.spannedText: In these groups, antibody titres should be determined 7 to 14 days after completing the pre-exposure or post-exposure immunization series to ensure that an acceptable antibody concentration has been achieved

classMention.mentionClass: In these groups, antibody titres should be determined 7 to 14 days after completing the pre-exposure or post-exposure immunization series to ensure that an acceptable antibody concentration has been achieved

annotation.spannedText: If vaccine is given by the ID route, post-immunization antibody titres should be determined at least 2 weeks after completion of the vaccine series, and after booster doses, to ensure that an acceptable level of protection has been achieved

classMention.mentionClass: If vaccine is given by the ID route, post-immunization antibody titres should be determined at least 2 weeks after completion of the vaccine series, and after booster doses, to ensure that an acceptable level of protection has been achieved

annotation.spannedText: HDCV (IMOVAX Rabies) should be store at +2C to +8C, and should not be used if it has been frozen

classMention.mentionClass: HDCV (IMOVAX Rabies) should be store at +2C to +8C, and should not be used if it has been frozen

annotation.spannedText: PCECV (RabAvert) should be store at +2C to +8C and protected from light

classMention.mentionClass: PCECV (RabAvert) should be store at +2C to +8C and protected from light

annotation.spannedText: Once reconstituted, these vaccines should be administered promptly

classMention.mentionClass: Once reconstituted, these vaccines should be administered promptly

annotation.spannedText: Vaccines should be provided at different injection sites using separate needles and syringes

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccines should be provided at different injection sites using separate needles and syringes

annotation.spannedText: There are no contraindications to the use of rabies vaccine or RabIg after significant exposure to a proven rabid animal; however, care should be taken if post-exposure prophylaxis is to be administered to persons who are hypersensitive to the products or to any ingredient in the formulation or component of the container (i.e. latex)

classMention.mentionClass: There are no contraindications to the use of rabies vaccine or RabIg after significant exposure to a proven rabid animal; however, care should be taken if post-exposure prophylaxis is to be administered to persons who are hypersensitive to the products or to any ingredient in the formulation or component of the container (i.e. latex)

annotation.spannedText: Expert opinion should be sought in the management of these individuals

classMention.mentionClass: Expert opinion should be sought in the management of these individuals

annotation.spannedText: Persons with a proven history of hypersensitivity to the vaccine or any component of the vaccine or its container should not be given the vaccine for pre-exposure immunization if possible

classMention.mentionClass: Persons with a proven history of hypersensitivity to the vaccine or any component of the vaccine or its container should not be given the vaccine for pre-exposure immunization if possible

annotation.spannedText: for pre-exposure vaccination, an alternative vaccine, HDCV, should be used in vaccinees with a history of hypersensitivity reactions to egg or egg products

classMention.mentionClass: for pre-exposure vaccination, an alternative vaccine, HDCV, should be used in vaccinees with a history of hypersensitivity reactions to egg or egg products

annotation.spannedText: If an alternative vaccine is not available, post-exposure prophylaxis using PCECV should be administered to a person with a hypersensitivity to egg with strict medical monitoring

classMention.mentionClass: If an alternative vaccine is not available, post-exposure prophylaxis using PCECV should be administered to a person with a hypersensitivity to egg with strict medical monitoring

annotation.spannedText: Facilities for emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions should be available

classMention.mentionClass: Facilities for emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions should be available

annotation.spannedText: The existing titre of rabies antibodies should be determined and expert opinion in the management of these individuals should be sought promptly

classMention.mentionClass: The existing titre of rabies antibodies should be determined and expert opinion in the management of these individuals should be sought promptly

annotation.spannedText: Pre-exposure immunization with rabies vaccine should be postponed in persons with moderate or severe acute illness

classMention.mentionClass: Pre-exposure immunization with rabies vaccine should be postponed in persons with moderate or severe acute illness

annotation.spannedText: Post-exposure vaccination should never be postponed

classMention.mentionClass: Post-exposure vaccination should never be postponed

annotation.spannedText: Wherever possible, an immunization series should be completed with the same product

classMention.mentionClass: Wherever possible, an immunization series should be completed with the same product
